title: 108_s985
content: ADJUSTED DIFFERENTIALS. Paragraph (1) of section 404(b) of the Federal Law Enforcement Pay Reform Act of 1990 is amended. The adjusted differentials for various metropolitan statistical areas range from 15.97% to 25.68%. The metropolitan statistical areas with adjusted differentials ranging from 13.29% to 30.39% include Detroit-Ann Arbor-Flint, Hartford, Houston-Galveston-Brazoria, Huntsville, Indianapolis, Kansas City, Los Angeles-Riverside-Orange County, Miami-Fort Lauderdale, Milwaukee, and Minneapolis-St. Paul. The metropolitan statistical areas with adjusted differentials ranging from 13.29% to 30.39% include Minneapolis-St. Paul, New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island, Orlando, Philadelphia-Wilmington-Atlantic City, Pittsburgh, Portland-Salem, Richmond, Sacramento-Yolo, and San Diego. The metropolitan statistical areas with adjusted differentials ranging from 13.29% to 32.98% include San Diego, San Francisco-Oakland-San Jose, Seattle-Tacoma-Bremerton, St. Louis, and Washington-Baltimore. Special rules apply to certain counties in Rhode Island, Maine, and New Hampshire. The Boston-Worcester-Lawrence, MA-NH-ME-CT-RI Consolidated Metropolitan Statistical Area is included in the amendment, which designates Capitol Police as law enforcement officers under the Federal Law Enforcement Pay Reform Act of 1990. The effective date of the amendment is retroactive to the enactment of the original Act and applies to pay for service in subsequent pay periods. Separate pay, evaluation, and promotion system for federal law enforcement officers is established. The Office of Personnel Management will study and submit a report to Congress on the need for a separate pay, evaluation, and promotion system for Federal law enforcement officers. If deemed appropriate, a demonstration project will be implemented within 12 months. The Office of Personnel Management will implement a demonstration project within 12 months to determine if a separate system for Federal law enforcement officers would improve personnel management. The project will follow provisions of title 5, United States Code, and a report will be submitted to Congress before the project's termination date. The Office of Personnel Management will evaluate a system tested in a demonstration project for Federal law enforcement officers and make recommendations to Congress on its continuation or extension. The term "Federal law enforcement officer" is defined as per title 5, United States Code. Section 3 limits premium pay for Federal law enforcement officers by amending Section 5547 of title 5, United States Code. The effective date of these amendments is retroactive to the enactment of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2002.
